title: Can I join Ph.D. degree after my high school? - Quora

response.answer_text: The common career path would go as follows: Graduate high school well enough to be accepted into a UniversityStudy for 3–4 years to get your bachelors or undergraduate degree as a prerequisite for obtaining a masters degreeStudy for 2 years to get your masters degree or graduate degreeApply to a PhD programAs I’ve come to know, some universities in some countries let you pursue a PhD straight after your bachelors, so you’d end up with 3+4=7 years of studies. I suppose that’s more for people who are oriented towards a career in Academia and you’d then be looking at at least one or two post-doctoral appointments, each somewhere around 2 years. As a physics professor told me, then you pretty much only get a PhD for three main reasons: You’re interested in it and want to know moreYou want a career in Academia and you can’t do it without a PhDThe job you want to have required a PhD in some fieldUnless it’s one of those three, you don’t need a PhD and you’re totally fine with just a masters. But to my knowledge, which of course is limited, I don’t know of any programs that allow you to do only four years of studies (equivalent to a bachelors program) and then give you the right to be called “doctor”. To me, after having spent five years in university, I don’t think it’s wise, reasonable or warranted. A PhD means you have mastered your field and unless you are a truly, truly unique and gifted individual, it is very unlikely you’d succeed in four years right after high school. I don’t recommend it. Plus, every smaller defense prepared you for the big one - it can be hours.

Sure you can - as long as you meet the requirements for entry to the program. However you’re unlikely to find a program that doesn’t require a bachelors and likely even a masters degree in the field, including very specific expectations for which courses you’ve taken and how you’ve performed in them. And to be considered for entry to most doctoral programs you’ll need endorsements from professors in the form of letters of recommendation. Not to be negative, but - good luck with that.

I suppose it would be possible in a very rare circumstance (which I really can’t envision). However, it’s highly unlikely and improbable. My experience is that doctoral programs require at least a bachelor’s degree as a prerequisite; the degree need not be in the same course of study, but the college is looking to see if the candidate can handle the rigor of college study. Also, many colleges also require a master’s degree as a prerequisite for doctoral study. There are notable exceptions to this, but it’s important that the candidate read and understand the admission requirements at the college or university he or she is applying to.

Yes, but not immediately. Depending on the country you’re in (and the results you get beforehand), you’ll need at least an undergraduate university degree to qualify for a PhD. In some places - and with some results - you’ll also need a masters-level degree as well. Obviously you’ll need to have completed secondary education before you move into tertiary education, but you won’t be able to graduate from school and go straight into PhD research.

I came across a bright young man who graduated with the bachelor's degree and high school diploma at 18. He could have tried to join PhD. If you have enough AP credits, you can also finish your bachelor's and later begin PhD.

I did. But I had 16 years of experience, published papers, and high recommendations before I applied (at age 37). And the reason was that I could not have studied CS in 1958 since it was not taught then. Assess your competence before you apply. You don’t tell us why you think you are prepared.
